same

side thing, I *think* that we could make a more generic astype in  ``indexes.base`` and remove *some* boiler plate *maybe* (of course separate PR), you can make an issue if you want (or just PR!)

For some reason ``freq='B'`` had to be handled differently because it was causing a lot of resample tests to fail when handled in the same way as all the other freq values. Not sure if this is a bug or if there is a better way of handling this.

I think could just remove this entirely here if ``_wrap_setop_result`` is defined in ``Index.base`` AND you move ``_apply_meta`` functionaily to inside of ``_shallow_copy`` for PI. (could also do this as a followup), but want to try to avoid duplicating ``_wrap_setup_result`` everywhere.

The reason we can't move it to base from category is because in the case of category, we need to preserve the categories, and in the case of period, we need to preserve frequency. 

So we could investigate in a separate PR about moving the `_apply_meta()` functionality.

Would this be easier to push through if `_add_offset` were separated from the rest of the PR?  This doesn't change any behavior, but does let us remove a particularly inelegant piece of code.
well, you are adding code here, not removing code, so not sure what is changing

comments.body:
So from some printing in the tests, some exploration on what is passed here:

- PeriodArray and int64 ndarray ordinals. I think those both are fine, it will probably hard to avoid mixing both? Or do we want a separate one for ordinals?
- object array of Periods. 
  - One example of this is `PeriodIndex.difference` (from the base Index implementation). This base implementation basically works, except that there is a `sorting.safe_sort` call on the resulting PeriodArray, which destroys the PeriodArray. But this is of course solvable in `sorting.safe_sort`, by making that EA aware.
  - So I think eventually we could try to solve all those cases where object is passed. But I would say, let's leave that for follow-ups ?
- None -> this is from plain `self.shallow_copy()` calls without arguments. This is fine I think.
This is basically what motivated #23095.  Even if the solution is unwanted there, I think it identifies all the extant places where unwanted types are currently passed to _shallow_copy

I think this delegation is a good idea for the dtype-specific ones, but it might be more explicit to keep general ones as `size` and `shape` as actual properties calling the underlying values (but could be shared for the different index classes based on EA). 
Anyway, not that important for this PR, this can be refactored after converting all Arrays.
Yah, I'm not wild about this.  I still think the best option is to nail down the constructors before doing the whole PeriodArray changeover.

On principle shouldn't we be avoiding DatetimeIndex._simple_new here?  The performance impact can't be that big a deal can it?

Sidenote: probably should have a to_index method for DatetimeArray etc, so this last line just becomes `return result.to_index(name=self.name)`

> On principle shouldn't we be avoiding DatetimeIndex._simple_new here?

In principle yes, but since our default constructors are that convoluted (and that is not something we can easily change), I think we should consider the `_simple_new` as an "internal public" method, meaning that we can use it throughout the pandas codebase (so outside it's own class definition where one can do `self._simple_new`)

> probably should have a to_index method for DatetimeArray etc

Personally, I think Arrays should be completely ignorant of the Index concept. That keeps a clearer separation of concerns

> Personally, I think Arrays should be completely ignorant of the Index concept

That's fair.  `arr.to_index()` really isn't any less verbose than `pd.Index(arr)`

comments.body: Any particular reason for PeriodIndex instead of type(self) or shallow_copy?
What is the performance implication of using _simple_new vs just Int64Index(...)?  If its sufficiently small, we should be using the public constructors

Relatively it is a big difference:

```
In [8]: values = np.arange(100000)

In [9]: %timeit pd.Index(values)
31 µs ± 140 ns per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10000 loops each)

In [10]: %timeit pd.Index._simple_new(values)
1.62 µs ± 26.1 ns per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 1000000 loops each)
```

but if that will be significant in actual code, I don't know.

But since we are using that in many places, I leave changing `_simple_new` calls to the public constructor for another PR.

@jbrockmendel this leads a bit further, but given that the public constructors (`__init__`) of Index classes are very complex (something we will not be able to change I think), I think that we need to see `_simple_new` as kind of a "internal public" method within the pandas code base.
what is this needed?

join between PeriodIndex and another type raises this error that I have not looked into yet:
TypeError: int() argument must be a string, a bytes-like object or a number, not 'Period'

This would not have been reached before since _assert_can_do_setop required the `other` type to also be PeriodIndex, but that is not longer the case.
hmm, is there a specific test that hits this?

See the following test:

pandas/tests/indexes/datetimes/test_datetime.py
test_join_with_period_index
this should be in assert_can_do_setop for PeriodIndex

`assert_can_do_setop` takes precedence over `_union_incompatible_dtypes`. So if we put it in there, we will no longer be able to union PeriodIndex with anything else, which was one of the original motivators for this PR.

Instead perhaps I can perform the _is_dtype_compatible check here instead.
Or maybe a separate, stricter, `_can_do_join method`?

yeah this might need some re-working. a PI can only union with a compatible PI, otherwise its converted to object. But this is true generally for all index types. So not sure why PI needs special logic. Its possible that it is not following the same paths as the other indices (e.g. check DTI & TDI).
What is this section for?
Collecting things that will soon be changed by the inheritance/composition in one place.  For PeriodIndex its a pretty small set
why is this the only index sublcass that you need to do this for?

It's the only extension-array backed index that's using the formatting right now.

- CategoricalIndex always uses the default formatter for the underlying categories (since it can be a container for any type, it dispatches the formatting).
- IntervalIndex /IntervalArray don't use this formatting

Datetime / TImedelta will use this too, so this will be pushed up into `DatetimeIndexOpsMixin` later.
cc @jbrockmendel I had to make this change here. Not sure how this actually worked before.

Note, there's a slight bit of duplication here with the PeriodIndexConstructor.

We can't call `PeriodIndex.__init__` from here, since then we hit the warning.

We can't call `period_range` from `PeriodIndex.__init__` since `period_range` doesn't handle fields.

In the end, it's just two lines, so I think we're OK.

comments.body: why is this just a warning? should raise, no?
IOW, passing ``freq`` only makes sense if start/end are NOT periods. furthermore we must have start.freq == end.freq if they are periods (and then would raise if freq is not None)

We're deprecating the behavior `pd.DatetimeIndex(start=..., periods=...)`, so a warning is appropriate.

The additional logic starting on this line is to determine whether or not `pd.date_range` is an *exact* replacement for what the user was previously doing. The default `freq` differ when `start` or `end` is passed as a string.

* `PeriodIndex` will infer the freq from start, so `pd.Period("2000")` has A-DEC freq.
* The default freq for `period_range` is `'D'`.

```
In [6]: pd.PeriodIndex(start='2000', periods=4)
/Users/taugspurger/.virtualenvs/pandas-dev/bin/ipython:1: FutureWarning: Creating a PeriodIndex by passing range endpoints is deprecated.  Use `pandas.period_range` instead. Note that the default `freq` may differ. Pass 'freq="A-DEC"' to ensure the same output.
  #!/Users/taugspurger/Envs/pandas-dev/bin/python3
Out[6]: PeriodIndex(['2000', '2001', '2002', '2003'], dtype='period[A-DEC]', freq='A-DEC')

In [7]: pd.period_range(start="2000", periods=4)
Out[7]: PeriodIndex(['2000-01-01', '2000-01-02', '2000-01-03', '2000-01-04'], dtype='period[D]', freq='D')
```

comments.body: should we be using weakref in the other invocations for consistency?

weakrefs cause some tests to fail.

I'm not sure currently if those failures are correct, could be worth an investigation. @crepererum , did you investigate if weakrefs not working is the correct behaviour?

No, I didn't test this.

IMHO, the weakref isn't required in the other cases since we're passing a member of `self` and not `self` itself. Using a weakref seemed to make things only unnecessary complicated, since then you have just a chain of indirections (`lambda->scope->weakref->self->member` instead of `lambda->scope->member`).
